text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A draft law to cut the period of police detention in line with Europe is presented to parliament.
- Main opposition leader Mesut Yilmaz says his office is being bugged by the state.
- A Turk resident in Hungary, Veysel Ozerdem, says he attacked Yilmaz in a Budapest hotel at the weekend because of the politician's criticism of a far-right gangster.
- Ozerdem says Turkey has organisation of "secret civilians" working for it.
- International Monetary Fund report rings alarm bells for Turkish economy.
- Experts split on whether the health ministry decision to treat drug addicts by giving them methadon is the right approach.
- Government preparing to reduce import tax on South Korean make of cars from 30 percent to ten percent.
- Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller sentenced to pay four billion Turkish lira compensation for slandering current coalition partner Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan during election campaign.
- Parliament is to meet to extend emergency rule for another four months in southeast Turkey.
